Description: The main frame that supports all components
Curved panels above the wheels to catch road debris
Often heavy and chrome-trimmed  with unique handles and hinges
Usually round and chrome-bezeled; sometimes separate pods
Red rear lights
Sometimes integrated into fenders or bumpers
Large chrome bars at front and rear for protection
Iconic front design element (e.g.  vertical slats on Rolls-Royce)
Often small and mounted on doors or fenders
Shiny metal wheel.
Classic tires with white sidewalls
Rubber guards behind tires to block splashes
Sometimes split down the middle in old models
Often manually rolled up with crank handles
Small triangular windows for airflow
Decorative figure (e.g.  the Spirit of Ecstasy on Rolls-Royce)
Mounted on rear or side often with chrome trim.
Sometimes exposed and decorative
Metal base structure that supports the seat and cush
Shaped padding that provides comfort and maintains seat form
Upholstery material that gives seats their classic vintage appearance
Padded rests that provide comfort and style to door interiors
Manual handles used to raise or lower car windows
Chrome or metal levers for opening doors from the inside
Set of gauges displaying speed fuel level
Control knobs for headlights wipers
Storage compartment built into the dashboard for small items
Classic control wheel that defines the car’s driving feel
Chrome ring used for honking and as a decorative feature
Lever for indicating direction changes in vintage vehicles
Cut-to-fit floor coverings matching original car specifications
Rubber or loop-pile mats for protecting the car’s carpet
Rubber pads providing grip on clutch brake
Fabric covering the interior ceiling for a smooth finish
Adjustable panels blocking sunlight glare for drivers and passengers
Fixture holding the cabin light  adding vintage illumination
Chrome-finish mirror providing clear rear visibility
Analog clock adding elegance and authenticity to the dashboard
Retro-style AM/FM radio with optional modern Bluetooth upgrade
Provides electrical energy to start the engine and power accessories
Charges the battery and powers the electrical system when the engine is running
Protects electrical circuits from overloads
Converts battery voltage to high voltage for spark plugs
Ignite the air-fuel mixture in engine cylinders
Directs high-voltage electricity to the correct spark plug
Early AM/FM radios powered by the car battery.
Main housing containing cylinders and crankcase for internal components.
Replaceable sleeves providing a smooth surface for piston movement.
Lower part of the block holding crankshaft and lubricating oil.
Converts combustion pressure into mechanical force.
Seal combustion chamber and control oil flow.
Links piston to crankshaft to transmit motion.
Converts piston movement into rotational energy.
Support crankshaft rotation inside the block.
Stores rotational energy and helps start the engine.
Seals the top of cylinders and holds valve components.
Control intake of air-fuel and exhaust of gases.
Transmit camshaft motion to open valves.
Controls valve timing and sequence.
Connects crankshaft and camshaft ensuring synchronized motion.
Push rods up and down following camshaft lobes.
Mixes air and fuel for combustion in proper ratio.
Distributes air-fuel mixture to cylinders evenly.
Delivers fuel from tank to carburetor.
Circulates oil through engine for lubrication.
Removes impurities from circulating oil.
Dissipates heat from the coolant to maintain temperature.
Collects exhaust gases and directs them out of cylinders.
Reduces exhaust noise from the engine.
Seals gap between engine block and cylinder head.
